Annotator Metadata.Steps:
1. Searched "ScienceDirect" on Google.
2. Opened the ScienceDirect website.
3. Clicked on the top listed domain in the Life Science section on the main page (Agricultural and Biological Sciences).
4. Clicked on "Reference works" in the filters.
5. Noted the number at the top.
6. Subtracted the number that had 2023 or later as a date.
7. Changed the domain to the following one and noted the number.
8. Repeated step 6 for all Life Science domains.
9. Calculated the sample standard deviation (16.195678435929).
10. Went back to the home page.
11. Repeated steps 3-9 for Health Science (15.926916420534).
12. Subtracted 16.195678435929 - 15.926916420534.
13. Rounded to the third decimal place.

 CCL-EAR COMMITTEE REVIEW
Elsevier ScienceDirect Health & Life Sciences Journals (College Edition)
October 2011

ScienceDirect Health & Life Sciences Journals is published by Elsevier, one of the world's
largest providers of scientific, technical and medical information. Elsevier’s ScienceDirect is a
modular package:  it offers colleges the possibility to subscribe to one or more of the three
subject collections. There is also the option to choose online access to journals, pre-1995 journals
content and/or books. Content areas include:

•  Health & Life Sciences
•  Social & Behavioral Sciences
•  Physical Sciences

This review refers specifically to the Health & Life Sciences collection.

OVERALL RECOMMENDATION for COMMUNITY COLLEGES: 3, 3, 3

#1 --- Not recommended
#2 --- Recommended with reservations as noted
#3 --- Recommended
#4 --- Outstanding offer

This collection offers community colleges affordable access to high quality, full-text peer-
reviewed research journals in the health and life sciences disciplines at a price and subscription
model that is amenable to community college library budgets.  Community colleges requiring in-
depth coverage of science titles for transfer-level academic coursework are unlikely to find a
comparable package elsewhere, so if providing this specific journal content is important to an
institution, a subscription to this database may be a cost-effective way to obtain this content.

The database may not, however, meet the needs of community college students who may be
inexperienced database searchers. Several idiosyncrasies associated with the interface covered
below may frustrate even the most experienced searcher and present instruction and reference
problems for library staff. Because the emphasis of this collection is on scholarly, peer-reviewed
literature, this collection may not be suitable for vocational studies programs requiring more
practical or applied literature.

RATINGS FOR SPECIFIC ASPECTS OF THE DATABASE:
The following features were examined and rated on a four point scale (1=Poor; 2= Needs
Improvement; 3=Good; 4=Excellent):

1

 DATABASE CONTENT/FORMAT 3.5, 4, 4
Consider functionality, appropriateness of format, database content, adequacy of coverage
retrospective, current), and value to the California Community Colleges as a whole.

ScienceDirect Health & Life Sciences Journals/College Edition offers searchers online access to
approximately 900 full-text research journals published by Elsevier. (Title counts are based on
vendor-supplied title lists and because numbers vary over time, reviewers recommend that
subscribing libraries confirm title coverage with the vendor prior to subscribing.)  Although the
collection is most useful for upper-division studies and research, it is appropriate for some
advanced transfer-level academic coursework taught at the community college level.  The
database comprises a comprehensive range of subjects in scholarly, peer-reviewed titles in
subjects such as medicine, pharmacy, physical therapy, midwifery, dentistry, veterinary
medicine, biology, environmental science, agricultural science, horticulture, and other life
science subjects.

 Additional subject coverage is provided for in areas such as geographic information systems and
engineering. Examples of titles include The Lancet, Nursing Outlook, Plant Science, Water
Research, and Ocean Engineering. For a full title list see
http://www.info.sciverse.com/techsupport/journals/colhealthlife.htm.

Coverage dates from 1995 to the current year. (Elsevier offers a pre-1995 back-file of the same
and discontinued titles as a separate subscription. The title list also includes titles that appear in
the pre-1995 back-file.) Unlike other Elsevier online journal collection subscriptions that are
based on a perpetual access purchase model, this collection is available on subscription model
that is familiar to and desired by community college libraries. The ScienceDirect College Edition
is an access only model (no archival rights after cancellation of subscription) and is based on a
calendar year subscription.

A subscription to the Health and Life Sciences collection in ScienceDirect includes access to the
publisher’s entire citation and abstract database of journals and books, including those included
in the other content collections you may not subscribe to. Having access to the vendor’s other
collections poses challenges to researchers and students that are noted below.

SEARCH INTERFACE 2, 2, 2

amount of training required? Are any crucial features missing from the search interface?

used fields, including journal/article title, author, keyword, volume, and issue.

 CCL-EAR COMMITTEE REVIEW
Elsevier ScienceDirect Health & Life Sciences Journals (College Edition)
October 2011

ScienceDirect Health & Life Sciences Journals is published by Elsevier, one of the world's
largest providers of scientific, technical and medical information. Elsevier’s ScienceDirect is a
modular package:  it offers colleges the possibility to subscribe to one or more of the three
subject collections. There is also the option to choose online access to journals, pre-1995 journals
content and/or books. Content areas include:

•  Health & Life Sciences
•  Social & Behavioral Sciences
•  Physical Sciences

This review refers specifically to the Health & Life Sciences collection.

OVERALL RECOMMENDATION for COMMUNITY COLLEGES: 3, 3, 3

#1 --- Not recommended
#2 --- Recommended with reservations as noted
#3 --- Recommended
#4 --- Outstanding offer

This collection offers community colleges affordable access to high quality, full-text peer-
reviewed research journals in the health and life sciences disciplines at a price and subscription
model that is amenable to community college library budgets.  Community colleges requiring in-
depth coverage of science titles for transfer-level academic coursework are unlikely to find a
comparable package elsewhere, so if providing this specific journal content is important to an
institution, a subscription to this database may be a cost-effective way to obtain this content.

The database may not, however, meet the needs of community college students who may be
inexperienced database searchers. Several idiosyncrasies associated with the interface covered
below may frustrate even the most experienced searcher and present instruction and reference
problems for library staff. Because the emphasis of this collection is on scholarly, peer-reviewed
literature, this collection may not be suitable for vocational studies programs requiring more
practical or applied literature.

RATINGS FOR SPECIFIC ASPECTS OF THE DATABASE:
The following features were examined and rated on a four point scale (1=Poor; 2= Needs
Improvement; 3=Good; 4=Excellent):

1

 DATABASE CONTENT/FORMAT 3.5, 4, 4
Consider functionality, appropriateness of format, database content, adequacy of coverage
retrospective, current), and value to the California Community Colleges as a whole.

ScienceDirect Health & Life Sciences Journals/College Edition offers searchers online access to
approximately 900 full-text research journals published by Elsevier. (Title counts are based on
vendor-supplied title lists and because numbers vary over time, reviewers recommend that
subscribing libraries confirm title coverage with the vendor prior to subscribing.)  Although the
collection is most useful for upper-division studies and research, it is appropriate for some
advanced transfer-level academic coursework taught at the community college level.  The
database comprises a comprehensive range of subjects in scholarly, peer-reviewed titles in
subjects such as medicine, pharmacy, physical therapy, midwifery, dentistry, veterinary
medicine, biology, environmental science, agricultural science, horticulture, and other life
science subjects.

 Additional subject coverage is provided for in areas such as geographic information systems and
engineering. Examples of titles include The Lancet, Nursing Outlook, Plant Science, Water
Research, and Ocean Engineering. For a full title list see
http://www.info.sciverse.com/techsupport/journals/colhealthlife.htm.

Coverage dates from 1995 to the current year. (Elsevier offers a pre-1995 back-file of the same
and discontinued titles as a separate subscription. The title list also includes titles that appear in
the pre-1995 back-file.) Unlike other Elsevier online journal collection subscriptions that are
based on a perpetual access purchase model, this collection is available on subscription model
that is familiar to and desired by community college libraries. The ScienceDirect College Edition
is an access only model (no archival rights after cancellation of subscription) and is based on a
calendar year subscription.

A subscription to the Health and Life Sciences collection in ScienceDirect includes access to the
publisher’s entire citation and abstract database of journals and books, including those included
in the other content collections you may not subscribe to. Having access to the vendor’s other
collections poses challenges to researchers and students that are noted below.

SEARCH INTERFACE 2, 2, 2
Consider the functionality and ease of use of the interface. Is it intuitive or is an excessive
amount of training required? Are any crucial features missing from the search interface?

Searching is divided into familiar modes (Quick, Browse, Advanced), but getting to desired
results using any of these options may not be intuitive for either a novice or an experienced
searcher.

Quick Search

The quick search form that appears at the top of the screen offers simple searching of commonly-
used fields, including journal/article title, author, keyword, volume, and issue.

2

 CCL-EAR COMMITTEE REVIEW
Elsevier ScienceDirect Health & Life Sciences Journals (College Edition)
October 2011

ScienceDirect Health & Life Sciences Journals is published by Elsevier, one of the world's
largest providers of scientific, technical and medical information. Elsevier’s ScienceDirect is a
modular package:  it offers colleges the possibility to subscribe to one or more of the three
subject collections. There is also the option to choose online access to journals, pre-1995 journals
content and/or books. Content areas include:

•  Health & Life Sciences
•  Social & Behavioral Sciences
•  Physical Sciences

This review refers specifically to the Health & Life Sciences collection.

OVERALL RECOMMENDATION for COMMUNITY COLLEGES: 3, 3, 3

#1 --- Not recommended
#2 --- Recommended with reservations as noted
#3 --- Recommended
#4 --- Outstanding offer

This collection offers community colleges affordable access to high quality, full-text peer-
reviewed research journals in the health and life sciences disciplines at a price and subscription
model that is amenable to community college library budgets.  Community colleges requiring in-
depth coverage of science titles for transfer-level academic coursework are unlikely to find a
comparable package elsewhere, so if providing this specific journal content is important to an
institution, a subscription to this database may be a cost-effective way to obtain this content.

The database may not, however, meet the needs of community college students who may be
inexperienced database searchers. Several idiosyncrasies associated with the interface covered
below may frustrate even the most experienced searcher and present instruction and reference
problems for library staff. Because the emphasis of this collection is on scholarly, peer-reviewed
literature, this collection may not be suitable for vocational studies programs requiring more
practical or applied literature.

RATINGS FOR SPECIFIC ASPECTS OF THE DATABASE:
The following features were examined and rated on a four point scale (1=Poor; 2= Needs
Improvement; 3=Good; 4=Excellent):

1

 DATABASE CONTENT/FORMAT 3.5, 4, 4
Consider functionality, appropriateness of format, database content, adequacy of coverage
retrospective, current), and value to the California Community Colleges as a whole.

ScienceDirect Health & Life Sciences Journals/College Edition offers searchers online access to
approximately 900 full-text research journals published by Elsevier. (Title counts are based on
vendor-supplied title lists and because numbers vary over time, reviewers recommend that
subscribing libraries confirm title coverage with the vendor prior to subscribing.)  Although the
collection is most useful for upper-division studies and research, it is appropriate for some
advanced transfer-level academic coursework taught at the community college level.  The
database comprises a comprehensive range of subjects in scholarly, peer-reviewed titles in
subjects such as medicine, pharmacy, physical therapy, midwifery, dentistry, veterinary
medicine, biology, environmental science, agricultural science, horticulture, and other life
science subjects.

 Additional subject coverage is provided for in areas such as geographic information systems and
engineering. Examples of titles include The Lancet, Nursing Outlook, Plant Science, Water
Research, and Ocean Engineering. For a full title list see
http://www.info.sciverse.com/techsupport/journals/colhealthlife.htm.

Coverage dates from 1995 to the current year. (Elsevier offers a pre-1995 back-file of the same
and discontinued titles as a separate subscription. The title list also includes titles that appear in
the pre-1995 back-file.) Unlike other Elsevier online journal collection subscriptions that are
based on a perpetual access purchase model, this collection is available on subscription model
that is familiar to and desired by community college libraries. The ScienceDirect College Edition
is an access only model (no archival rights after cancellation of subscription) and is based on a
calendar year subscription.

A subscription to the Health and Life Sciences collection in ScienceDirect includes access to the
publisher’s entire citation and abstract database of journals and books, including those included
in the other content collections you may not subscribe to. Having access to the vendor’s other
collections poses challenges to researchers and students that are noted below.

SEARCH INTERFACE 2, 2, 2

searcher.

used fields, including journal/article title, author, keyword, volume, and issue.

### 1. Task outcome (short version):
We need to locate the authoritative ScienceDirect report (or dataset) from 2022 that lists the counts of Reference Works by domain – separating Life Sciences (by individual domains within Life Sciences) from Health Sciences – and then prepare for computing the sample standard deviation (with n–1 as denominator) for the counts of each group, and finally the difference between those two standard deviations (Life Sciences minus Health Sciences).

### 2. Task outcome (extremely detailed version):

1. Facts given in the task  
 • The target is an authoritative ScienceDirect report or dataset.  
 • The data is as of 2022.  
 • The report provides counts of Reference Works.  
 • The counts are divided into two groups: counts per individual Life Science domains (explicitly not including Health Sciences) and the counts for Health Sciences as a whole.  
 • The next step after obtaining the counts is to confirm the lists (i.e., verify the actual numeric counts) and then perform statistical computations – specifically, to compute the sample standard deviation (using n–1 in the denominator) for each group and finally to calculate the difference between the standard deviation of Life Science domains and that of the Health Sciences, rounded to three decimal places.

2. Facts to look up  
 • The exact ScienceDirect report or dataset:  
  – Source: ScienceDirect website or any cited official reports/datasets distributed by Elsevier/ScienceDirect.  
  – Verification that the report is indeed from 2022 and covers the “Reference Works” counts as required.  
 • Detailed definitions and boundaries for the domains:  
  – What qualifies as a “Reference Work” in this context.  
  – Which specific subjects or categories are considered under Life Sciences (ensuring Health Sciences are excluded from this group) versus Health Sciences proper.  
  – Where in the report these categorizations are clearly delineated.  
 • The location of the dataset within the report (for example, specific sections, tables, appendices) so that the individual numeric counts are extractable.  
 • If the report is in PDF or non-HTML format, tools like “inspect_file_as_text” may be needed to manually search the document for the specific numbers.

3. Facts to derive  
 • Extraction of the individual counts:  
  – From the report, derive the list of counts for each Life Science domain.  
  – Also, derive the count (or list, if applicable) for Health Sciences.  
 • Statistical calculations:  
  – Compute the sample standard deviation for the list of Life Sciences domain counts. (Ensure to use n–1 in the denominator.)  
  – Compute the sample standard deviation for the Health Sciences count(s).  
  – Calculate the difference between the two standard deviations (Life Sciences minus Health Sciences).  
  – Round the final difference result to three decimal places.  
 • Logical connection:  
  – Confirm and verify that the dataset’s divisions and counts match the requirements before performing the statistical computations.

### 3. Additional context (if relevant):
This preparatory survey identifies the steps required to ensure that the search for the correct ScienceDirect report is thorough and that the subsequent numerical extraction and statistical analysis are correctly scoped. The survey stresses the need for precise definitions (e.g., what exactly constitutes a Reference Work and how domains are segmented) and emphasizes the importance of verifying the source document’s date (2022) to ensure data relevancy. Any uncertainty or missing details about the categorization or report structure should prompt further clarification or additional research on ScienceDirect’s publication archives.

1. Facts given in the task:
 • The task requires finding an authoritative ScienceDirect report or dataset from 2022.
 • This report should provide counts of Reference Works categorized by domain.
 • The counts should be split into two groups: individual counts for Life Sciences domains (excluding Health Sciences) and a separate count for Health Sciences.
 • Once the counts are confirmed, the sample standard deviation (using n–1 in the denominator) is to be computed for each group.
 • Finally, the difference between the standard deviations (Life Sciences minus Health Sciences) is needed, rounded to three decimal places.

2. Facts that we have learned:
 • Several ScienceDirect-related documents and pages from 2022 were identified, but none clearly match the specific description of a 2022 report listing counts of Reference Works by Life Sciences domain and Health Sciences.
 • A 2011 CCL (Council of Chief Librarians) review was located which discusses the ScienceDirect Health & Life Sciences Journals collection; however, this document does not satisfy the task requirement because:
  – It is from 2011, not 2022.
  – It provides a review and ratings rather than the detailed counts of Reference Works needed.
 • Other search results pertain to various ScienceDirect articles and bibliometric studies, but none clearly present a dataset with the count breakdown needed.

3. Facts still to look up:
 • The exact authoritative ScienceDirect report or dataset from 2022 that details the counts of Reference Works.
 • Precise clarification on what qualifies as a “Reference Work” within the ScienceDirect context.
 • The list of specific Life Sciences domains used in the report (ensuring Health Sciences are excluded from that group) and the one aggregate count for Health Sciences.
 • The location or section in the report (table or appendix) where these counts are provided.
 • Confirmation that the document’s publication date is indeed 2022 to ensure data relevancy.

4. Facts still to derive:

 • Compute the sample standard deviation for the Life Sciences domain counts (using n–1 as the denominator).
 • Compute the sample standard deviation for the Health Sciences count(s) if applicable (or treat it as a single data point if that is the case, which may require clarification).
 • Derive the difference between the standard deviation computed for Life Sciences domains and that for Health Sciences.
 • Round the final computed difference to three decimal places.

 CCL-EAR COMMITTEE REVIEW
Elsevier ScienceDirect Health & Life Sciences Journals (College Edition)
October 2011

ScienceDirect Health & Life Sciences Journals is published by Elsevier, one of the world's
largest providers of scientific, technical and medical information. Elsevier’s ScienceDirect is a
modular package:  it offers colleges the possibility to subscribe to one or more of the three
subject collections. There is also the option to choose online access to journals, pre-1995 journals
content and/or books. Content areas include:

•  Health & Life Sciences
•  Social & Behavioral Sciences
•  Physical Sciences

This review refers specifically to the Health & Life Sciences collection.

OVERALL RECOMMENDATION for COMMUNITY COLLEGES: 3, 3, 3

#1 --- Not recommended
#2 --- Recommended with reservations as noted
#3 --- Recommended
#4 --- Outstanding offer

This collection offers community colleges affordable access to high quality, full-text peer-
reviewed research journals in the health and life sciences disciplines at a price and subscription
model that is amenable to community college library budgets.  Community colleges requiring in-
depth coverage of science titles for transfer-level academic coursework are unlikely to find a
comparable package elsewhere, so if providing this specific journal content is important to an
institution, a subscription to this database may be a cost-effective way to obtain this content.

The database may not, however, meet the needs of community college students who may be
inexperienced database searchers. Several idiosyncrasies associated with the interface covered
below may frustrate even the most experienced searcher and present instruction and reference
problems for library staff. Because the emphasis of this collection is on scholarly, peer-reviewed
literature, this collection may not be suitable for vocational studies programs requiring more
practical or applied literature.

RATINGS FOR SPECIFIC ASPECTS OF THE DATABASE:
The following features were examined and rated on a four point scale (1=Poor; 2= Needs
Improvement; 3=Good; 4=Excellent):

1

 DATABASE CONTENT/FORMAT 3.5, 4, 4
Consider functionality, appropriateness of format, database content, adequacy of coverage
retrospective, current), and value to the California Community Colleges as a whole.

ScienceDirect Health & Life Sciences Journals/College Edition offers searchers online access to
approximately 900 full-text research journals published by Elsevier. (Title counts are based on
vendor-supplied title lists and because numbers vary over time, reviewers recommend that
subscribing libraries confirm title coverage with the vendor prior to subscribing.)  Although the
collection is most useful for upper-division studies and research, it is appropriate for some
advanced transfer-level academic coursework taught at the community college level.  The
database comprises a comprehensive range of subjects in scholarly, peer-reviewed titles in
subjects such as medicine, pharmacy, physical therapy, midwifery, dentistry, veterinary
medicine, biology, environmental science, agricultural science, horticulture, and other life
science subjects.

 Additional subject coverage is provided for in areas such as geographic information systems and
engineering. Examples of titles include The Lancet, Nursing Outlook, Plant Science, Water
Research, and Ocean Engineering. For a full title list see
http://www.info.sciverse.com/techsupport/journals/colhealthlife.htm.

Coverage dates from 1995 to the current year. (Elsevier offers a pre-1995 back-file of the same
and discontinued titles as a separate subscription. The title list also includes titles that appear in
the pre-1995 back-file.) Unlike other Elsevier online journal collection subscriptions that are
based on a perpetual access purchase model, this collection is available on subscription model
that is familiar to and desired by community college libraries. The ScienceDirect College Edition
is an access only model (no archival rights after cancellation of subscription) and is based on a
calendar year subscription.

A subscription to the Health and Life Sciences collection in ScienceDirect includes access to the
publisher’s entire citation and abstract database of journals and books, including those included
in the other content collections you may not subscribe to. Having access to the vendor’s other
collections poses challenges to researchers and students that are noted below.

SEARCH INTERFACE 2, 2, 2
Consider the functionality and ease of use of the interface. Is it intuitive or is an excessive
amount of training required? Are any crucial features missing from the search interface?

Searching is divided into familiar modes (Quick, Browse, Advanced), but getting to desired
results using any of these options may not be intuitive for either a novice or an experienced
searcher.

Quick Search

The quick search form that appears at the top of the screen offers simple searching of commonly-
used fields, including journal/article title, author, keyword, volume, and issue.

=======================
 CCL-EAR COMMITTEE REVIEW
Elsevier ScienceDirect Health & Life Sciences Journals (College Edition)
October 2011

ScienceDirect Health & Life Sciences Journals is published by Elsevier, one of the world's
largest providers of scientific, technical and medical information. Elsevier’s ScienceDirect is a
modular package:  it offers colleges the possibility to subscribe to one or more of the three
subject collections. There is also the option to choose online access to journals, pre-1995 journals
content and/or books. Content areas include:

•  Health & Life Sciences
•  Social & Behavioral Sciences
•  Physical Sciences

This review refers specifically to the Health & Life Sciences collection.

OVERALL RECOMMENDATION for COMMUNITY COLLEGES: 3, 3, 3

#1 --- Not recommended
#2 --- Recommended with reservations as noted
#3 --- Recommended
#4 --- Outstanding offer

This collection offers community colleges affordable access to high quality, full-text peer-
reviewed research journals in the health and life sciences disciplines at a price and subscription
model that is amenable to community college library budgets.  Community colleges requiring in-
depth coverage of science titles for transfer-level academic coursework are unlikely to find a
comparable package elsewhere, so if providing this specific journal content is important to an
institution, a subscription to this database may be a cost-effective way to obtain this content.

The database may not, however, meet the needs of community college students who may be
inexperienced database searchers. Several idiosyncrasies associated with the interface covered
below may frustrate even the most experienced searcher and present instruction and reference
problems for library staff. Because the emphasis of this collection is on scholarly, peer-reviewed
literature, this collection may not be suitable for vocational studies programs requiring more
practical or applied literature.

RATINGS FOR SPECIFIC ASPECTS OF THE DATABASE:
The following features were examined and rated on a four point scale (1=Poor; 2= Needs
Improvement; 3=Good; 4=Excellent):

1

 DATABASE CONTENT/FORMAT 3.5, 4, 4
Consider functionality, appropriateness of format, database content, adequacy of coverage
retrospective, current), and value to the California Community Colleges as a whole.

ScienceDirect Health & Life Sciences Journals/College Edition offers searchers online access to
approximately 900 full-text research journals published by Elsevier. (Title counts are based on
vendor-supplied title lists and because numbers vary over time, reviewers recommend that
subscribing libraries confirm title coverage with the vendor prior to subscribing.)  Although the
collection is most useful for upper-division studies and research, it is appropriate for some
advanced transfer-level academic coursework taught at the community college level.  The
database comprises a comprehensive range of subjects in scholarly, peer-reviewed titles in
subjects such as medicine, pharmacy, physical therapy, midwifery, dentistry, veterinary
medicine, biology, environmental science, agricultural science, horticulture, and other life
science subjects.

 Additional subject coverage is provided for in areas such as geographic information systems and
engineering. Examples of titles include The Lancet, Nursing Outlook, Plant Science, Water
Research, and Ocean Engineering. For a full title list see
http://www.info.sciverse.com/techsupport/journals/colhealthlife.htm.

Coverage dates from 1995 to the current year. (Elsevier offers a pre-1995 back-file of the same
and discontinued titles as a separate subscription. The title list also includes titles that appear in
the pre-1995 back-file.) Unlike other Elsevier online journal collection subscriptions that are
based on a perpetual access purchase model, this collection is available on subscription model
that is familiar to and desired by community college libraries. The ScienceDirect College Edition
is an access only model (no archival rights after cancellation of subscription) and is based on a
calendar year subscription.

A subscription to the Health and Life Sciences collection in ScienceDirect includes access to the
publisher’s entire citation and abstract database of journals and books, including those included
in the other content collections you may not subscribe to. Having access to the vendor’s other
collections poses challenges to researchers and students that are noted below.

SEARCH INTERFACE 2, 2, 2
Consider the functionality and ease of use of the interface. Is it intuitive or is an excessive
amount of training required? Are any crucial features missing from the search interface?

Searching is divided into familiar modes (Quick, Browse, Advanced), but getting to desired
results using any of these options may not be intuitive for either a novice or an experienced
searcher.

Quick Search

The quick search form that appears at the top of the screen offers simple searching of commonly-
used fields, including journal/article title, author, keyword, volume, and issue.

 CCL-EAR COMMITTEE REVIEW
Elsevier ScienceDirect Health & Life Sciences Journals (College Edition)
October 2011

ScienceDirect Health & Life Sciences Journals is published by Elsevier, one of the world's
largest providers of scientific, technical and medical information. Elsevier’s ScienceDirect is a
modular package:  it offers colleges the possibility to subscribe to one or more of the three
subject collections. There is also the option to choose online access to journals, pre-1995 journals
content and/or books. Content areas include:

•  Health & Life Sciences
•  Social & Behavioral Sciences
•  Physical Sciences

This review refers specifically to the Health & Life Sciences collection.

OVERALL RECOMMENDATION for COMMUNITY COLLEGES: 3, 3, 3

#1 --- Not recommended
#2 --- Recommended with reservations as noted
#3 --- Recommended
#4 --- Outstanding offer

This collection offers community colleges affordable access to high quality, full-text peer-
reviewed research journals in the health and life sciences disciplines at a price and subscription
model that is amenable to community college library budgets.  Community colleges requiring in-
depth coverage of science titles for transfer-level academic coursework are unlikely to find a
comparable package elsewhere, so if providing this specific journal content is important to an
institution, a subscription to this database may be a cost-effective way to obtain this content.

The database may not, however, meet the needs of community college students who may be
inexperienced database searchers. Several idiosyncrasies associated with the interface covered
below may frustrate even the most experienced searcher and present instruction and reference
problems for library staff. Because the emphasis of this collection is on scholarly, peer-reviewed
literature, this collection may not be suitable for vocational studies programs requiring more
practical or applied literature.

RATINGS FOR SPECIFIC ASPECTS OF THE DATABASE:
The following features were examined and rated on a four point scale (1=Poor; 2= Needs
Improvement; 3=Good; 4=Excellent):

1

 DATABASE CONTENT/FORMAT 3.5, 4, 4
Consider functionality, appropriateness of format, database content, adequacy of coverage
retrospective, current), and value to the California Community Colleges as a whole.

ScienceDirect Health & Life Sciences Journals/College Edition offers searchers online access to
approximately 900 full-text research journals published by Elsevier. (Title counts are based on
vendor-supplied title lists and because numbers vary over time, reviewers recommend that
subscribing libraries confirm title coverage with the vendor prior to subscribing.)  Although the
collection is most useful for upper-division studies and research, it is appropriate for some
advanced transfer-level academic coursework taught at the community college level.  The
database comprises a comprehensive range of subjects in scholarly, peer-reviewed titles in
subjects such as medicine, pharmacy, physical therapy, midwifery, dentistry, veterinary
medicine, biology, environmental science, agricultural science, horticulture, and other life
science subjects.

 Additional subject coverage is provided for in areas such as geographic information systems and
engineering. Examples of titles include The Lancet, Nursing Outlook, Plant Science, Water
Research, and Ocean Engineering. For a full title list see
http://www.info.sciverse.com/techsupport/journals/colhealthlife.htm.

Coverage dates from 1995 to the current year. (Elsevier offers a pre-1995 back-file of the same
and discontinued titles as a separate subscription. The title list also includes titles that appear in
the pre-1995 back-file.) Unlike other Elsevier online journal collection subscriptions that are
based on a perpetual access purchase model, this collection is available on subscription model
that is familiar to and desired by community college libraries. The ScienceDirect College Edition
is an access only model (no archival rights after cancellation of subscription) and is based on a
calendar year subscription.

A subscription to the Health and Life Sciences collection in ScienceDirect includes access to the
publisher’s entire citation and abstract database of journals and books, including those included
in the other content collections you may not subscribe to. Having access to the vendor’s other
collections poses challenges to researchers and students that are noted below.

SEARCH INTERFACE 2, 2, 2

amount of training required? Are any crucial features missing from the search interface?

Searching is divided into familiar modes (Quick, Browse, Advanced), but getting to desired
results using any of these options may not be intuitive for either a novice or an experienced
searcher.

The quick search form that appears at the top of the screen offers simple searching of commonly-
used fields, including journal/article title, author, keyword, volume, and issue.

 CCL-EAR COMMITTEE REVIEW
Elsevier ScienceDirect Health & Life Sciences Journals (College Edition)
October 2011

ScienceDirect Health & Life Sciences Journals is published by Elsevier, one of the world's
largest providers of scientific, technical and medical information. Elsevier’s ScienceDirect is a
modular package:  it offers colleges the possibility to subscribe to one or more of the three
subject collections. There is also the option to choose online access to journals, pre-1995 journals
content and/or books. Content areas include:

•  Health & Life Sciences
•  Social & Behavioral Sciences
•  Physical Sciences

This review refers specifically to the Health & Life Sciences collection.

OVERALL RECOMMENDATION for COMMUNITY COLLEGES: 3, 3, 3

#1 --- Not recommended
#2 --- Recommended with reservations as noted
#3 --- Recommended
#4 --- Outstanding offer

This collection offers community colleges affordable access to high quality, full-text peer-
reviewed research journals in the health and life sciences disciplines at a price and subscription
model that is amenable to community college library budgets.  Community colleges requiring in-
depth coverage of science titles for transfer-level academic coursework are unlikely to find a
comparable package elsewhere, so if providing this specific journal content is important to an
institution, a subscription to this database may be a cost-effective way to obtain this content.

The database may not, however, meet the needs of community college students who may be
inexperienced database searchers. Several idiosyncrasies associated with the interface covered
below may frustrate even the most experienced searcher and present instruction and reference
problems for library staff. Because the emphasis of this collection is on scholarly, peer-reviewed
literature, this collection may not be suitable for vocational studies programs requiring more
practical or applied literature.

RATINGS FOR SPECIFIC ASPECTS OF THE DATABASE:
The following features were examined and rated on a four point scale (1=Poor; 2= Needs
Improvement; 3=Good; 4=Excellent):

1

 DATABASE CONTENT/FORMAT 3.5, 4, 4

retrospective, current), and value to the California Community Colleges as a whole.

ScienceDirect Health & Life Sciences Journals/College Edition offers searchers online access to
approximately 900 full-text research journals published by Elsevier. (Title counts are based on
vendor-supplied title lists and because numbers vary over time, reviewers recommend that
subscribing libraries confirm title coverage with the vendor prior to subscribing.)  Although the
collection is most useful for upper-division studies and research, it is appropriate for some
advanced transfer-level academic coursework taught at the community college level.  The
database comprises a comprehensive range of subjects in scholarly, peer-reviewed titles in
subjects such as medicine, pharmacy, physical therapy, midwifery, dentistry, veterinary
medicine, biology, environmental science, agricultural science, horticulture, and other life
science subjects.

 Additional subject coverage is provided for in areas such as geographic information systems and
engineering. Examples of titles include The Lancet, Nursing Outlook, Plant Science, Water
Research, and Ocean Engineering. For a full title list see
http://www.info.sciverse.com/techsupport/journals/colhealthlife.htm.

Coverage dates from 1995 to the current year. (Elsevier offers a pre-1995 back-file of the same
and discontinued titles as a separate subscription. The title list also includes titles that appear in
the pre-1995 back-file.) Unlike other Elsevier online journal collection subscriptions that are
based on a perpetual access purchase model, this collection is available on subscription model
that is familiar to and desired by community college libraries. The ScienceDirect College Edition
is an access only model (no archival rights after cancellation of subscription) and is based on a
calendar year subscription.

A subscription to the Health and Life Sciences collection in ScienceDirect includes access to the
publisher’s entire citation and abstract database of journals and books, including those included
in the other content collections you may not subscribe to. Having access to the vendor’s other

1. Facts given in the task:
 • The task requires finding an authoritative ScienceDirect report or dataset from 2022.
 • This report should provide counts of Reference Works categorized by domain.
 • The counts should be split into two groups: individual counts for Life Sciences domains (excluding Health Sciences) and a separate count for Health Sciences.
 • Once the counts are confirmed, the sample standard deviation (using n–1 in the denominator) is to be computed for each group.
 • Finally, the difference between the standard deviations (Life Sciences minus Health Sciences) is needed, rounded to three decimal places.

2. Facts that we have learned:
 • Several ScienceDirect-related documents and pages from 2022 were identified, but none clearly match the specific description of a 2022 report listing counts of Reference Works by Life Sciences domain and Health Sciences.
 • A 2011 CCL (Council of Chief Librarians) review was located which discusses the ScienceDirect Health & Life Sciences Journals collection; however, this document does not satisfy the task requirement because:
  – It is from 2011, not 2022.
  – It provides a review and ratings rather than the detailed counts of Reference Works needed.
 • Other search results pertain to various ScienceDirect articles and bibliometric studies, but none clearly present a dataset with the count breakdown needed.

3. Facts still to look up:
 • The exact authoritative ScienceDirect report or dataset from 2022 that details the counts of Reference Works.
 • Precise clarification on what qualifies as a “Reference Work” within the ScienceDirect context.
 • The list of specific Life Sciences domains used in the report (ensuring Health Sciences are excluded from that group) and the one aggregate count for Health Sciences.
 • The location or section in the report (table or appendix) where these counts are provided.
 • Confirmation that the document’s publication date is indeed 2022 to ensure data relevancy.

4. Facts still to derive:
 • Once the appropriate report/dataset is identified, extract the individual numeric counts for each Life Sciences domain.
 • Extract the count(s) for Health Sciences.

=======================
 CCL-EAR COMMITTEE REVIEW
Elsevier ScienceDirect Health & Life Sciences Journals (College Edition)
October 2011

ScienceDirect Health & Life Sciences Journals is published by Elsevier, one of the world's
largest providers of scientific, technical and medical information. Elsevier’s ScienceDirect is a
modular package:  it offers colleges the possibility to subscribe to one or more of the three
subject collections. There is also the option to choose online access to journals, pre-1995 journals
content and/or books. Content areas include:

•  Health & Life Sciences
•  Social & Behavioral Sciences
•  Physical Sciences

This review refers specifically to the Health & Life Sciences collection.

OVERALL RECOMMENDATION for COMMUNITY COLLEGES: 3, 3, 3

#1 --- Not recommended
#2 --- Recommended with reservations as noted
#3 --- Recommended
#4 --- Outstanding offer

This collection offers community colleges affordable access to high quality, full-text peer-
reviewed research journals in the health and life sciences disciplines at a price and subscription
model that is amenable to community college library budgets.  Community colleges requiring in-
depth coverage of science titles for transfer-level academic coursework are unlikely to find a
comparable package elsewhere, so if providing this specific journal content is important to an
institution, a subscription to this database may be a cost-effective way to obtain this content.

The database may not, however, meet the needs of community college students who may be
inexperienced database searchers. Several idiosyncrasies associated with the interface covered
below may frustrate even the most experienced searcher and present instruction and reference
problems for library staff. Because the emphasis of this collection is on scholarly, peer-reviewed
literature, this collection may not be suitable for vocational studies programs requiring more
practical or applied literature.

RATINGS FOR SPECIFIC ASPECTS OF THE DATABASE:
The following features were examined and rated on a four point scale (1=Poor; 2= Needs
Improvement; 3=Good; 4=Excellent):

1

 DATABASE CONTENT/FORMAT 3.5, 4, 4
Consider functionality, appropriateness of format, database content, adequacy of coverage
retrospective, current), and value to the California Community Colleges as a whole.

ScienceDirect Health & Life Sciences Journals/College Edition offers searchers online access to
approximately 900 full-text research journals published by Elsevier. (Title counts are based on
vendor-supplied title lists and because numbers vary over time, reviewers recommend that
subscribing libraries confirm title coverage with the vendor prior to subscribing.)  Although the
collection is most useful for upper-division studies and research, it is appropriate for some
advanced transfer-level academic coursework taught at the community college level.  The
database comprises a comprehensive range of subjects in scholarly, peer-reviewed titles in
subjects such as medicine, pharmacy, physical therapy, midwifery, dentistry, veterinary
medicine, biology, environmental science, agricultural science, horticulture, and other life
science subjects.

 Additional subject coverage is provided for in areas such as geographic information systems and
engineering. Examples of titles include The Lancet, Nursing Outlook, Plant Science, Water
Research, and Ocean Engineering. For a full title list see
http://www.info.sciverse.com/techsupport/journals/colhealthlife.htm.

Coverage dates from 1995 to the current year. (Elsevier offers a pre-1995 back-file of the same
and discontinued titles as a separate subscription. The title list also includes titles that appear in
the pre-1995 back-file.) Unlike other Elsevier online journal collection subscriptions that are
based on a perpetual access purchase model, this collection is available on subscription model
that is familiar to and desired by community college libraries. The ScienceDirect College Edition
is an access only model (no archival rights after cancellation of subscription) and is based on a
calendar year subscription.

A subscription to the Health and Life Sciences collection in ScienceDirect includes access to the
publisher’s entire citation and abstract database of journals and books, including those included
in the other content collections you may not subscribe to. Having access to the vendor’s other
collections poses challenges to researchers and students that are noted below.

SEARCH INTERFACE 2, 2, 2

amount of training required? Are any crucial features missing from the search interface?

Searching is divided into familiar modes (Quick, Browse, Advanced), but getting to desired
results using any of these options may not be intuitive for either a novice or an experienced
searcher.

The quick search form that appears at the top of the screen offers simple searching of commonly-
used fields, including journal/article title, author, keyword, volume, and issue.
